Nack. Recommended driver depends on the Docker version being used. Kubernetes 1.7 only supports up to docker 1.12, where overlay2 is not recommended/mature. Kubernetes 1.8 supports up to 17.03, and tectonic will pick it up via torcx. New clusters installed directly on Docker 17.03 will default to overlay2.

```
diff --git a/Documentation/variables/azure.md b/Documentation/variables/azure.md
index 3698f402..03a3a2a6 100644
--- a/Documentation/variables/azure.md
+++ b/Documentation/variables/azure.md
@@ -25,8 +25,8 @@ This document gives an overview of variables used in the Azure platform of the T
 | tectonic_azure_master_storage_type | (optional) Storage account type for the master node(s). Example: Premium_LRS. Using Premium storage is constrained by the of instance specified in 'tectonic_azure_master_vm_size'. See https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/storage-premium-storage#supported-vms | string | `Premium_LRS` |
 | tectonic_azure_master_vm_size | (optional) Instance size for the master node(s). Example: Standard_DS2_v2. | string | `Standard_DS2_v2` |
 | tectonic_azure_ssh_key | (required) Path to an SSH public key file to be provisioned as the SSH key for the 'core' user. | string | - |
-| tectonic_azure_ssh_network_external | (optional) Network (external) to allow SSH access from. Maps to `source_address_prefix` in Azure. Defaults to `*`. Can be external to Azure environment. Allowed values: [network CIDR (i.e., 10.0.0.0/16) | `VirtualNetwork` | `Internet` | `*` ] | string | `*` |
-| tectonic_azure_ssh_network_internal | (optional) Network (internal) to allow SSH access from. Maps to `source_address_prefix` in Azure. Defaults to `VirtualNetwork`. Should be internal to Azure environment. Allowed values: [network CIDR (i.e., 10.0.0.0/16) | `VirtualNetwork` | `Internet` | `*` ] | string | `VirtualNetwork` |
+| tectonic_azure_ssh_network_external | (optional) Network (external) to allow SSH access from. Maps to `source_address_prefix` in Azure. Defaults to `*`. Can be external to Azure environment. Allowed values: [network CIDR (i.e., 10.0.0.0/16) \| `VirtualNetwork` \| `Internet` \| `*` ] | string | `*` |
+| tectonic_azure_ssh_network_internal | (optional) Network (internal) to allow SSH access from. Maps to `source_address_prefix` in Azure. Defaults to `VirtualNetwork`. Should be internal to Azure environment. Allowed values: [network CIDR (i.e., 10.0.0.0/16) \| `VirtualNetwork` \| `Internet` \| `*` ] | string | `VirtualNetwork` |
 | tectonic_azure_vnet_cidr_block | (optional) Range of IP addresses assigned to the Virtual Network in which the cluster nodes run. This should not overlap with any other networks, such as the Kubernetes cluster (pod) range, service range or a private datacenter connected via ExpressRoute." | string | `10.0.0.0/16` |
 | tectonic_azure_worker_storage_type | (optional) Storage account type for the worker node(s). Example: Premium_LRS. Using Premium storage is constrained by the of instance specified in 'tectonic_azure_worker_vm_size'. See https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/storage-premium-storage#supported-vms | string | `Premium_LRS` |
 | tectonic_azure_worker_vm_size | (optional) Instance size for the worker node(s). Example: Standard_DS2_v2. | string | `Standard_DS2_v2` |
```

Thanks a lot for the PR! Generally this LGTM, but I would ask for one change:

We are autogenerating all the example files based off config.tf and platform/<name>/variables.tf.

We use this tool https://github.com/s-urbaniak/terraform-examples and this tool https://github.com/segmentio/terraform-docs and the `make docs examples` target to regenerate them.

If you don't mind:
1. install both tools
1. add a documentation string to https://github.com/coreos/tectonic-installer/blob/master/platforms/azure/variables.tf#L17 with a `(optional)` prefix which is understood by the terraform-example tool. If a variable is marked `(optional)` it will automatically comment it out in the generated examples.

I'm don't think this will work, looking at the example here - https://github.blog/changelog/2022-10-11-github-actions-deprecating-save-state-and-set-output-commands/

```
- name: Set output
run: echo "::set-output name={name}::{value}"
```

Becomes:

```
- name: Set output
run: echo "{name}={value}" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
```

So it looks like you will need to remove the set-output part as well.  Also look at the differences in the syntax between the name and value

This seems to be a new thing. If I recall correctly, only the source bucket required versioning enabled due to the way replication works. It seems that now both source and destination buckets require versioning enabled if replication is enabled.

Here is a relevant snippet from https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/replication.html: Both source and destination buckets must have versioning enabled. For more information about versioning, see Using versioning in S3 buckets.

Taking Local Links Manager as inspiration, I believe you only need to add a block to integration/staging/production `common.tfvars`: [example](https://github.com/alphagov/govuk-aws-data/blob/e61abc79e45934d5baabd6c2b8e37cced8bb3c02/data/app-govuk-rds/integration/common.tfvars#L172-L189). Then to make sure the `locations_api` node can access the RDS, you'd need to make changes to app-locations-api (like [Local Links Manager does to `backend`](https://github.com/alphagov/govuk-aws/blob/7fad0ad1298c92c58eb6f668090bf8a5cd6d9734/terraform/projects/app-backend/main.tf#L269-L281)). This looks good to me.

My spidey sense is just tingling slightly about the higher-than-average proportion of TLS 1 connections for `govuk-backend-public-elb` in your analysis. Perhaps there are some shonky clients talking to `hmrc-manuals-api` or something like that? Or perhaps one of the domains has just been picked up by some scanners.

In any case, I think the best way to find out would be to do it and see what breaks. If there are important users still using TLS 1.0 then we need to find out who they are and start a conversation with them about upgrading, and honestly that's much much easier to do by just seeing what breaks.

I wonder if it would be worth putting this up as scheduled maintenance on statuspage, so we've got something to point to if things break? Maybe for an hour, no expected downtime?

I think this should be pretty safe to push to www/cache/frontends (and if it breaks it'll just fall back to mirrors and it's an quick and easy rollback). For publishers there's a slight chance of issues if people are using outdated clients, but probably unlikely. For GOV.UK Licencing I wouldn't be at all surprised if there are local councils stuck on horribly outdated kit who might have issues, so we should be prepared for issues there. Ideally we'd have sent out comms well in advance, but OTOH TLS < 1.2 has been on borrowed time for ages now.

Logging lock waits seems totally uncontroversial, especially since you're investigating this area.

As you mention in your commit message, changing the deadlock_timeout feels a bit more controversial. I guess the effect of this is that users will have to wait 2.5 secs for an error, instead of 1 sec. If it was just email API that would be no problem, as it's all async. It's a shame to have to do it for all of our DBs, but since we share RDS instances aggressively I don't think that's entirely avoidable. Might be worth considering only updating it on app-postgresql, rather than on transition and content-data's DBs? But happy for this to be merged if you think it's better to be consistent.

SGTM - reasoning for both changes seems sound.

I don't think the controversy over deadlock_timeout is warranted, given what you've pointed out. It seems a very low-risk change to me for all the reasons already mentioned. I say go for it.

> only check for deadlocks 4 times rather than 10 times

That's a helpful argument. Since we don't expect deadlock for user-facing queries, the performance boost does seem to outweigh any negative user impact.

I don't think this will work. How it was previously
after the cluster bootstrapped i.e. installed critical components, it would:
- Remove the default priv psp
- Apply our psps
- Recycle all pods so the bootstrapped pods also picked up the psp

How i've interpreted it to work after this pr
after the cluster bootstrapped i.e. installed critical components, it would:
- Remove the default priv psp
- Recycle all pods so the bootstrapped pods would pick up something we don't want it to (the next psp in the list)
- Install our psps as part of the terraform components layer.

One change I think you should make is to have a "happy path" test as well. As written, your test will pass if the cluster is set up to raise a 403 error for every single URL request.

Personally, I'd structure your test like this;
```
context "when modsec is deployed" do
  context "when URL is benign" do
    it "allows the request
  end
  context "when URL is malicious" do
    it "denies the request"
  end
end

context "when modsec is not deployed" do
   ...same inner contexts as above, but the malicious URL is allowed, too
end
```

That will make it extremely clear to the reader what you're trying to do, and what modsec adds to the cluster. It also means the *only* way your tests can pass is if modsec is deployed and doing what it's supposed to do, correctly.

I am wondering if we are not making things to difficult for us. Can we reduce the complexity of our setup by putting a few conventions in place? For example:

- `infra-admins` is by default added to every account.
- For every account, we create a `${account_name}-admin` and `${account_name}-read` group with appropriate permissions sets.

Then we just have to manage users and can generate the assignments automatically from a list of account names. Because I expect that each account will only have 2-3 groups anyways: `infra-admins`, a group for maintainers, and maybe a read-only group.

This does assume that the "admin" access for all accounts looks the same, i.e. that we don't limit `docs-rs-staging` to just ECS and RDS, and `dev-desktop-prod` to just `EC2`. Which raises the bigger question on how we want to protect the accounts against mistakes/malice in the first place. `AdministratorAccess` might be a bit broad, and we probably want/need to create budget limits. The specifics of this are something we should discuss outside of this PR, however, we need to decide whether we want to apply generic admin privileges to all accounts.

Ok, in that case I'm fine with merging this and iterating in other PRs on the remaining questions. :+1:

I'd prefer to keep the pre-built lambda func zip in source since it represents what is actually in production.  Anyone can then dl the source and exec a terraform plan without having to build the zip.  In addition to that, the function build itself isn't entirely deterministic since there is no requirements.txt with versions and hashes pinned.  If a change, unrelated to the zip, needs to happen you'll end up having to build the zip which may likely have a different hash triggering the lambda being replaced and no rollback of the previous version should something go wrong with the new zip.  And since it is only one file, 2mb isn't that big to be a space concern.

hi @mark-gronow thanks for your PR! 

As Terraform is lazy at plan-time to evaluate the value with try statements, the ```public_ip_address_id``` as it is wouldnt be assesed at plan time. Meaning if you add a public ip address, even if not related to config file, it would create a "known at apply" message which could make ops teams anxious, as showed here: https://github.com/aztfmod/terraform-azurerm-caf/pull/1952#pullrequestreview-2013679247 . Do you think we could modify the statement in the same shape as described in the other PR? (a-la: ```disk_encryption_set_id = can(each.value.os_disk.disk_encryption_set_id) ? each.value.os_disk.disk_encryption_set_id : can(each.value.os_disk.disk_encryption_set_key) ? var.disk_encryption_sets[try(each.value.os_disk.lz_key, var.client_config.landingzone_key)][each.value.os_disk.disk_encryption_set_key].id : null)```

Can you please also check your example file for:
1. The right resource group keys.
2. The right vnet and subnet address space blocks.
3. Resource group for the NSG.
4. Remove the nsg flow logs since your example does not have diagnostics.

thanks for the PR @onlyillusion! Terraform is lazy at plan time, so with your statement, when you add a disk encryption set, even not related to the VM, you will get something like that: We try to have statements that force plan-time calculation to avoid that, this statement is evaluated at plan time, so it doesn't create a know after apply: ``` disk_encryption_set_id = can(each.value.os_disk.disk_encryption_set_id) ? each.value.os_disk.disk_encryption_set_id : can(each.value.os_disk.disk_encryption_set_key) ? var.disk_encryption_sets[try(each.value.os_disk.lz_key, var.client_config.landingzone_key)][each.value.os_disk.disk_encryption_set_key].id : null ``` @onlyillusion would you be able to test if the statement proposed above works for you and if so please update the PR for going ahead! thanks!

I would suggest keeping the skip file in place until after the upgrade has finished, or it's not doing anything useful.

`defaultRequest` means "reserve this much resource for me, and prevent anyone else in the cluster from using it"

Unless you are absolutely certain you need to do this, it's a bad idea because it leads to the cluster running out of available resources.

This namespace is using less than half of the currently-reserved CPU for each pod, so I don't think this change is advisable:
```
$ kubectl -n court-probation-dev top pods
NAME                                         CPU(cores)   MEMORY(bytes)
court-case-matcher-58b569b8fb-hc8zk          4m           367Mi
court-case-service-54c4d6b76d-brbrs          4m           617Mi
court-case-service-54c4d6b76d-s9pvc          5m           473Mi
court-list-mock-data-6945d79466-ctn6v        1m           53Mi
crime-portal-gateway-b9d948c85-cqr9v         4m           313Mi
port-forward-pod-6fb56d74c-48qlh             0m           0Mi
prepare-a-case-75c956f5-wzvtd                1m           34Mi
probation-court-prototype-58c44cdf4f-js8mv   1m           268Mi
```
There is more information about `limit` and `defaultRequest` in [this article](https://user-guide.cloud-platform.service.justice.gov.uk/documentation/concepts/namespace-limits.html#namespace-container-resource-limits)

The plan step threw up a different error:
```
executing: kubectl -n check-financial-eligibility-uat apply --dry-run -f namespaces/live-1.cloud-platform.service.justice.gov.uk/check-financial-eligibility-uat
Command: kubectl -n check-financial-eligibility-uat apply --dry-run -f namespaces/live-1.cloud-platform.service.justice.gov.uk/check-financial-eligibility-uat failed.
error: error validating "namespaces/live-1.cloud-platform.service.justice.gov.uk/check-financial-eligibility-uat/05-ingress.yaml": error validating data: [ValidationError(Ingress.spec): unknown field "ingress" in io.k8s.api.networking.v1beta1.IngressSpec, ValidationError(Ingress.spec): unknown field "podSelector" in io.k8s.api.networking.v1beta1.IngressSpec, ValidationError(Ingress.spec): unknown field "policyTypes" in io.k8s.api.networking.v1beta1.IngressSpec]; if you choose to ignore these errors, turn validation off with --validate=false
```

Are you able to run `kubectl -n [your namespace] apply -f ingress.yaml --dry-run` to check whether this is going to work before you raise the PR?

That's a valid configmap definition, so the pipeline is happy, but it's not going to affect anything because the ingress controller isn't going to do anything with a configmap in your namespace.

You need to apply configuration changes in your ingress definition, like this:
https://docs.nginx.com/nginx-ingress-controller/configuration/ingress-resources/advanced-configuration-with-annotations/

Try using the `nginx.org/server-tokens` annotation in your ingress definition, and see if it does what you want. Failing that, see if you can do what you need via `nginx.org/server-snippets`, like in the example on that page.

Ideally, we'd prefer people not use `defaultRequest` because this ring-fences cluster resources for the pod(s), *whether or not the pod uses them*.

In the past, we've had a lot of problems with resources being reserved for pods that didn't need them, leading to artificial resource shortages in the cluster.

If you're confident that at least your `defaultRequest` CPU and memory will always be used by these pods, please go ahead and merge your PR. But, if you're not sure, please leave the `defaultRequest` as is. 

The change to `default` will allow your pods to consume resources up to the limits you've specified, whenever they need them.

More info [here](https://user-guide.cloud-platform.service.justice.gov.uk/documentation/concepts/namespace-limits.html#namespace-container-resource-limits)

I think "batch" is an apiGroup, not a resource. 
e.g. https://github.com/ministryofjustice/cloud-platform-environments/blob/0c53ba203f5b31bc6d026be82a6a149a5df22a53/namespaces/live-1.cloud-platform.service.justice.gov.uk/hmpps-book-secure-move-api-dev/06-serviceaccount-circleci.yaml#L43

I don't think this is the change you want to make. By changing the apiGroup from "" to "batch" you're restricting the resources on which you're granting permissions.

I think I was half-right earlier - "batch" seems to be used as both an apiGroup and a resource, e.g. 
https://github.com/ministryofjustice/cloud-platform-environments/blob/main/namespaces/live-1.cloud-platform.service.justice.gov.uk/contact-moj-development/08-service-account-circleci.yaml

I think your original change might have been correct.

Sorry, we're all working on today's incident, so I'm not able to spend as much time on PRs as usual.

Sorry Said - this one seems to have slipped through the cracks. We should have approved this days ago.

This is an S3 bucket that we're already added to the "allow public" list, right?

The database creation part of this is not going to work, because the cloud-platform-terraform-rds-instance module only supports postgres - just changing the database engine & family won't work.

Given that we (MoJ) hardly use other databases, the most straightforward solution here is probably to write terraform code that uses that standard AWS RDS terraform module, rather than our modified version of it, to set up a mariadb instance in the way you need it.

Is that something you could do, or would you like us to help with that?

In the meantime, if it's useful to have just the namespace without the database, please remove the rds part of this PR and we can get it merged.

@digitalronin, i think we will have to look into both the places. First check for "last-applied-configuration" in the annotations. if one not present look into the "apiVersion". 

For example, when i look into the "kubectl get deployment -n how-out-of-date-are-we -o yaml" which has the apiVersion changes, but still have the extensions/v1beta1 in it. And has the "last-configuration" with new apiVersion.
LGTM. You'll need to temporarily disable master branch protection to merge, because of the git-crypted `secrets.yaml` file in this namespace

You've got the "multiple queues cyclic dependency" problem described here:
https://github.com/ministryofjustice/cloud-platform-terraform-sqs#usage

You need to split this into 2 PRs by commenting out all but one of the queues, so that terraform knows which queue will *create* the IAM user, and the other queues will all *reuse* that IAM user.

As it stands, terraform has no way of knowing which is the queue that will create the IAM user, so it can't create *any* of the queues.

A couple of things:

First of all, this is a fairly big change, and it might take a couple of iterations to get it right, so I'd strongly recommend only working on a non-prod namespace at first, while you refine the code (unless you've already done that in a separate AWS account)

Secondly, it looks here as though you're re-using the existing database username and password, but sticking 'ro-' on the front.
This means that, if someone wanted the real root user and password, they could just remove the 'ro-' part of the credentials they have, and they would have them.
I know that's not really such a big deal, since anyone who can access the readonly secrets could also access the root secrets, but it does feel a bit icky.
Instead, you could use a fixed string for the username (e.g. "readonly-db-user") and a `random_password` resource like this for the password:
```
resource "random_password" "password" {
  length  = 16
  special = false
}
```
Then, you would create a kubernetes secret to store `random_password.password.result`, and use that to access your data.

You can see how the rds module does this, here:
https://github.com/ministryofjustice/cloud-platform-terraform-rds-instance/blob/1c2666d26e5c1818b731f757ead413e62987bfcb/main.tf#L29

@jsugarman Making the memory request value smaller will allow you to schedule more containers before you hit the namespace request limit of 6G of memory.

But, making the cpu requests higher means you'll hit the namespace CPU request limit of 300m sooner, so it will prevent you from scheduling containers.

I recommend leaving the cpu request limit at 10m, and lowering the memory request limit to 250Mi or even 100Mi, until you work out what you actually need.

As always these are "reservations" not limits, so you're not limiting the resources your containers can consume, via these values. But, the overall namespace request limits will block containers from being scheduled, if their total reservations exceed the limits.

- the namespaces used for the `ServiceAccounts` do not exist.

Additionally, may I suggest grouping access per platform environment (although I'm probably missing context about the intention here)? eg.:
```
apiVersion: v1
kind: ServiceAccount
metadata:
  name: circleci-formbuilder-services-test
  namespace: formbuilder-publisher-test
```
And then define the `RoleBindings` in the namespaces as you would. This leaves you with only one SA token per platform environment which would make it much easier to setup on CircleCI.

Thanks @escattone, this looks like a good companion for the Kuma changes.

The use of an ampersand `&` triggers bad memories of subtle `bash` bugs. The ampersand is used to execute the command in the background, so you can't type it at an interactive shell without escaping or quoting. However. it works in the docker environment (`docker-compose exec kumascript bash -c "env | grep url_template"`), and it appears to work in the `Makefile` as well without escaping. So I'm 95% sure it will work in deployments as well 😉.

Just one more thing... The `README.md` is generated from the `README.yaml`. Make all your changes to the `README.yaml` (if needed), then rebuild the `README.md` by running the following commands:
```
make init
make readme/deps
make readme
```

It will update the variables and inputs descriptions.
There might be a lot of changes in the `README.md` as a result. That's okay! 

Sorry for the inconvenience!

Once thing, don't make changes to `README.md` directly.
Update `README.yaml` instead (examples, and description if needed), and then rebuild README by executing these commands:

```
make init
make readme/deps
make readme
```

All resources need to be cluster-specific, as long as they are deployed in the context of the k8s-services module.

To ensure this, and consistent naming, the names of SNS, Lambda etc. need to be inferred and include the cluster name (in main.tf, like for traefik_alb_auth_dns.record_name). Suggestion:

SNS topic name: "alb_500_errors" --> "alb_500_errors_$ClusterName"
Lambda name: "cw_to_slack" --> "cw_to_slack_$ClusterName"

This means we need to pass cluster name to the sub-module, 

I think the input variables need to be more aligned with other sections, though I realise this is hardly documented at all:

- All input variables for this sub-module should have the same prefix
- The name/identifier of the module, should be the first part (until the first underscore)
- Though this is definitely closely related to Traefik and ALB, it's first and foremost a CloudWatch alarm
- We may want to have other CloudWatch alarms (e.g. for NLBs, or even something completely different), so it's still a good idea to include "alb"
- The input variables generically states "..._alb_...", but are specifically for a module for http 500 errors only - maybe use "..._alb_500_..." 

Suggested new input variables:

cw_alb_alerts_deploy --> cwalarms_alb_500_deploy
traefik_alb_slack_hook --> cwalarms_alb_500_slack_hook
traefik_alb_slack_channel --> cwalarms_alb_500_slack_channel
traefik_alb_lambda_name  --> none (infer value in module)
traefik_alb_sns_name --> none (infer value in module)

The "albs" variable passed to the sub-module is not very descriptive. Suggest change to "alb_arn_suffixes".

The way the list of alb_arn_suffixes could be greatly simplified, if the outputs from the ALB modules works like the FQDN output. Then you should able to just concat module.traefik_alb_anon.alb_arn_suffix and module.traefik_alb_auth.alb_arn_suffix. As mentioned above, this may be necessary to avoid breaking if one or more ALBs are toggled off.

Wanted to write here just some history on this function on copying files and why I didn't choose a pre-built solution. 

1. This code was written with the idea that we would be moving towards an extension system. Meaning that  we have multiple `src` directories with one `destination` directory.  
2. Not all "files" in src are coming from files. Some are computed e.g. the terraform `*.tf.json` files
3. There are cases to consider:
   - a file exists in multiple `src` directories... (decision: which one to choose?)
   - a file from a `src` doesn't exist in `destination` (decision: easy decision just copy over)
   - a file from a `src` is different in `destination` (decision: easy copy over since `src` is source of truth but use should be notified of change)
   - a file in `destination` exists that isn't in any `src` directories (decision: keep? but notify user there is an unwatched file?)

Basically the multiple src issue and dynamic generation of files is what led me to write those functions.
Weird those had execute permissions. Thanks for fixing that.

Great start except:

The field `keycloak` is optional in the schema so this could fail:
`config.get("security").get("keycloak").get("initial_root_password", False)`
(in deploy.py).

Obvious first response would be to use `get("keycloak", {})` but actually there are a lot of areas in the code where it assumes `keycloak` exists - so maybe safest to make it non-optional for now. (`initial_root_password` can still be optional of course)

Deployment fails if `initial_root_password` is removed from `qhub-config.yaml` - which it can be, according to the schema. This was a problem before your PR but makes sense to fix it here. I would suggest just defaulting to an empty string if not specified, e.g. within `stage_05_kubernetes_keycloak` function of `input_vars.py`.

Would also be good to add a comment in `qhub/template/stages/05-kubernetes-keycloak/outputs.tf` to note that output keycloak_qhub_bot_password is really redundant, and ideally upstream components would just use keycloak_credentials  now. (But not worth changing all the code to use it at this point - just a comment so people aren't too confused that it is sort of duplicated.)

This is a good start, but the changes to the upgrade process have been misunderstood.

Please completely reinstate the `Upgrade_0_3_12` class. Since 0.3.12 is an older version, there is no need to change that at all. At that point in time, for an upgrade to 0.3.12 we needed to add the `default_images.conda-store` field. We still do, in theory, for any upgrade to 0.3.12. (Although, of course, anyone running `qhub upgrade` with the latest code will actually be upgrading to 0.4.0. However, the way it works is that it can still upgrade from e.g. 0.3.10 to 0.4.0 by going through every intermediate step.)

So, anyway, what I really meant was that in `Upgrade_0_4_0` you need to do the opposite of what we did in `Upgrade_0_3_12`. We need to remove the `default_images.conda-store` key from the config.

If you look at `Upgrade_0_4_0` you can see we do some similar things there. We remove the `security.users` and `security.groups` fields, for example. We also remove a key called `terraform_modules`.

So have a think about how you could just add something similar to remove `default_images.conda-store` if it exists (which it should, but best to check).

And then we also need `qhub deploy` to work of course, so we need to think about how we can not pass in the `default_images.conda-store` field to the Terraform code, and just have it have a non-overridable default for the image within the Terraform code. Where we pass the image variable in now, we just need to ensure the variable is no longer available and we just have a raw string.

That will work fine, and I can approve. However, it is just worth noting that you could remove either:
```
        "conda-store-image": _split_docker_image_name(
            "quansight/conda-store-server:v0.3.9"
        ),
```
from `input_vars.py`
OR
```
  default = {
    name = "quansight/conda-store-server"
    tag  = "v0.3.9"
  }
```
from `conda-store/variables.tf`

You don't actually need both! However, it is perfectly acceptable how you have done it because you could argue that you want the separation between the script in input_vars.py and the Terraform module for conda-store. Maybe you think that the Terraform module should be able to be self-contained (and still have a default image) in case whatever calls it doesn't want to pass through the image name, for any reason.

Of course, right now the two sections of code are tightly-coupled and always located close by in the same relatively-small codebase.

So on the other hand, you might not like the way you have essentially duplicated the number of places where you specify the default image name and tag. Imagine if we need to change the conda-store image within the QHub code (e.g. to v.3.10 when it comes out). You might only remember to do it in one place, at which point you might be specifying v0.3.9 in input_vars but v.0.3.10 in variables.tf - in which case you will end up still using v0.3.9 because it overrides the default. Or you might end up with it the other way round: specify v0.3.10 in input_vars but v0.3.9 in variables.tf, in which case you would end up using v0.3.10 after all, for the same reason - that input_vars overrides the default set in variables.tf.

The point here is that it would then be difficult to really know which version is in use just by looking at the code. It would be easy to only look at the wrong place and get the wrong answer.

I did some experimentation here just to better understand Terraform internals. It looks like TF is verifying the type within the map only in trenary operator. So the minimal fix for added example can look like that:
```diff
diff --git a/blueprints/factories/project-factory/factory.tf b/blueprints/factories/project-factory/factory.tf
index e0351a0a..53017266 100644
--- a/blueprints/factories/project-factory/factory.tf
+++ b/blueprints/factories/project-factory/factory.tf
@@ -16,10 +16,8 @@
 
 locals {
   _data = (
-    var.factory_data.data != null
-    ? var.factory_data.data
-    : {
-      for f in fileset("${local._data_path}", "**/*.yaml") :
+    {
+      for f in fileset(local._data_path, "**/*.yaml") :
       trimsuffix(f, ".yaml") => yamldecode(file("${local._data_path}/${f}"))
     }
   )
```

That is, just refactoring the variable and getting rid of `factory.data` is sufficient. :exploding_head:

First, since we're deciding we can't account for dynamic values in additive roles, we can now collapse the two variables into a single one. A map with users as keys and roles list as values would be clearer, and also highlight the fact these have different behaviour vs authoritative roles. I would call it `iam_additive_bindings`.

Hey, I think you are missing the AmazonSSMManagedInstanceCore policy - 
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/systems-manager/latest/userguide/setup-instance-profile.html#instance-profile-policies-overview

The other policies add additional S3 functionality, but I think you'll need the core SSM policy as well (unless it's elsewhere and I've missed it!)

```
resource "aws_iam_role_policy_attachment" "ssm_policy" {
  policy_arn = "arn:aws:iam::aws:policy/AmazonSSMManagedInstanceCore"
  role       = aws_iam_role.ppud_data_transfer_role.name
}
```

I believe this will still fail because the usage in the eip definition. Since you're iterating over a `count` object in `resource "aws_network_interface" "proxy-nlb-master-nic"`, you're effectively defining `count` number of ENIs. In your eip definition, you'll have to do something similar with this line in the `aws_eip` block.

```
network_interface         = aws_network_interface.proxy-nlb-master-nic.id
```

Essentially you need to map each ENI to an EIP.  

Remember that an EIP can only be mapped to a single ENI

@cvittoriasona Thank you for this contribution. We appreciate the effort.

This module is not currently accepting PRs due to the master branch containing breaking changes that will be replaced. Until the master branch is fixed, PRs are on hold.

Meanwhile, would you please verify that you can use `var.userdata_override_base64` with `var.kubernetes_taints`. The [AWS documentation says](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/eks/latest/userguide/launch-templates.html#launch-template-custom-ami):

> When specifying an AMI, Amazon EKS doesn't merge any user data. Rather, you're responsible for supplying the required bootstrap commands for nodes to join the cluster. If your nodes fail to join the cluster, the Amazon EKS CreateNodegroup and UpdateNodegroupVersion actions also fail.
 
When the user supplies userdata or taints, this module specifies a launch template with a custom AMI ID, and currently`var.kubernetes_taints` is ignored if you use `var.userdata_override_base64`. The thing is, I am pretty sure that the `taint` block also works by setting userdata parameters passed to `bootstrap.sh` so taints will continue to be ignored when you specify `var.userdata_override_base64`. 

So we are probably going to reject this request because it imposes the extra requirement on AWS Terraform provider version for not enough gain.

It will add the new variable to `README.md`.

In general, any changes to README should be made in `README.yaml` (not in this case), and after that executing the commands above will rebuild `README.yaml` into `README.md` and add all new variables and outputs to `README.md`

This kind of solution warrants a broader discussion and more investigation, because it is yet another workaround for wanting to have stability of plans/resources while still handling values unknown at plan time. I could be convinced that this is a path to go, but I would want to do a lot more testing before using it here.

Our current best solution is to allow people to supply either a map with labels known at plan time or a list whose length is known at plan time. This gives users control for the case when, in this example, the ARNs are not known at plan time, but perhaps keys for the ARNs can be known. For example, one ARN per region so the keys can be regions.

I don't see anything wrong with pipeing to xargs, but just as an idea:

My implementation was similar, but I assigned to variables and reused them, ex:

```
INTERNET_GW=$(aws ec2 create-internet-gateway --tag-specifications 'ResourceType=internet-gateway,Tags=[{Key=Name,Value=devopsacademy-igw}]' --query=InternetGateway.InternetGatewayId --output text)

aws ec2 attach-internet-gateway --internet-gateway-id $INTERNET_GW --vpc-id $VPC_ID

```


Also, you can default the output to `text` via your configuration or by setting 

```
export AWS_DEFAULT_OUTPUT="test"
```

I personally think adding the parameter like you did makes it more explicit (less margin for error), but just giving an idea.

Cheers,

In the AWS ECS service, you configure a `Task Definition`, which consists on the configuration that will be used to create the containers. Information like Image, port mapping, reserved CPU and memory and a few others.

the warning you've received is just to let you know that the certificate presented by the server you're trying to connect is being added to the list of known hosts.
you'll probably have a file in your laptop named `~/.ssh/known_hosts` that will contain all servers(ip address) that you have connected to and the keys associated with it.

if you delete that instance and create a new one with the same ip address and try to connect, you'll probably be unable to connect. 
Because your machine already knows that ip address and have a certificate associated with it and the new machine will have a different certificate, your machine will detect a risk and will not allow you to connect.

I don't think we should add these permissions to this role. This affects all workspaces. It may be ok to grant these permissions in some workspaces but blanket adding for all inhibits our ability implement policies that prevent these permission in some. Perhaps [deny policies](https://cloud.google.com/iam/docs/deny-access) could be used but they are not GA yet. Instead, perhaps there could be an explicit "enable nextflow" api for a workspace that would setup the right permissions.

Hi @dvoet, thanks for the PR!

A few preliminary comments:
* We're trying to avoid adding new applications to the terra-env module and instead run them in their own Atlantis project. This is to (1) reduce contention around Atlantis PR locks and Terraform state locks across teams and (2) avoid a giant state file that takes several minutes to preview and apply. See the [sam deployment here](https://github.com/broadinstitute/terraform-ap-deployments/tree/master/sam) as an example.

* Could you pick a short, single-word name for this new service so it can be referred to consistently in infrastructure? See DevOps [recommendations](https://github.com/broadinstitute/terra-helmfile/blob/master/docs/NAMING.md#applications) and [FAQ](https://github.com/broadinstitute/terra-helmfile/blob/master/docs/NAMING.md#faq) as well as guidelines from [Platform Foundations](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1yvVlQnXDKOKSKEKIsMrWNh0LfwLuI7FWt57sa43d7Qg/edit?usp=sharing)
Seems like a good approach to me.

@Simranpal The changes in the terraform part looks fine. But we need to do some changes in salt/pillar files part. Here some of changes I have found out (maybe there are more):
- `pillar_examples/automatic/netweaver/cluster.sls` the `install_packages` must be `false` if we are in `qa_mode`. The same for `drbd`. Check the example in hana pillar files.
- We need to change the netweaver formula. Right now, the packages are always installed, and in `qa_mode` we don't want this. Use this as a reference: https://github.com/SUSE/saphanabootstrap-formula/blob/master/hana/init.sls#L4
After that you will need to change the `netweaver.sls` pillar file too.
- `drbd` formula already has this feature. So, just update the `drbd` pillar file

Basically, we need to avoid the installation of any package that is not directly involved in the deployment (formulas, etc, must be installed)

As @arbulu89 mentioned, If we are using `qa_mode`, we have to by-pass packages installations from [here](https://github.com/SUSE/ha-sap-terraform-deployments/blob/develop/salt/drbd_node/drbd_packages.sls). This is what we are doing for a [hana node](https://github.com/SUSE/ha-sap-terraform-deployments/blob/develop/salt/hana_node/hana_packages.sls).

Here my thoughts on this PR:

Having the need to change the main.tf file content for not technical users will bring more issues than advantages (even technical users without experience with terraform).

So here the question is: 
Who are the users of this project? If it's focused for developers, I like the idea as it brings more flexibility and we can get rid of some enable/disable resource kind of flags anyway personally, I don't see them really a big problem). 
If it's for any other user, this will bring issues (requiring file editions always bring issues).
We should definitely provide a lot of main.tf example files in this case to make the usage easy (like basic hana deployment, deployment with monitoring solution, deployment with iscsi, deployment with netweaver, deployment with drbd).

And we have to provide them for all of the providers! Don't forget that, we are not only working for libvirt!

This new approach would be quite disruptive (it's true that we don't have any real user except us as far as I know). Let's think about this carefully, and not only as developers hehe

As previously discussed. - If a breaking change (MAJOR update to container occurs, this could cause an issue with operational support.) On the other hand, pinning the versions too specifically will risk expected functionality on later containers not to be present on an old pinned version. Thus also impacting operational support. 

I have done some research to see if it is possible to pin only the major version of the container e.g: `"v1.*.*"` however it does not look like there is an easy method to do this without big redesign. Given the risk is minor, I am happy to approve and will add this to the risk log.

I’ve put some questions below, but it’d be good to put the container builds design into a doc. I think it'd probably be better to answer the questions below in a doc, since it'll be easier to collaborate :D

Let me know if you would like to pair on writing a design doc for the container builds stuff.

- Is there a reason we've chosen to create a separate deployment module for ECR, rather than creating this within govuk-publishing-platform?
- Since most of the build-images.yml file is duplicated code, and will be quite large once other apps are added; should we remove the duplicate code by creating multiple pipelines from a smaller yaml file, and provide the varying parts as pipeline variables, e.g. `((git_repo_url))`?
- The pipeline pushes to one ECR (currently integration, but will switch to production). It'd be great if we could also push to DockerHub, but we should ensure we don't interfere with the current platform (e.g. perhaps pushing the `latest` tag can impact e2e tests). As an aside, as you mentioned before the ECR repo is private - is it possible to make it public with Terraform?
- It looks like tagging commits with `1.0.*-release` shouldn't affect the current platform. Are we happy using this versioning system? I presume we'll change the deploy pipeline to watch for commits tagged with `*-release` to trigger deploys.
- Currently we build an image when a new commit is merged into the main branch. Have you thought about where we'll run tests against the main branch before we build an image for it?

I think this is a slight improvement - it was confusing having both `service_name` and `mesh_subdomain`, and then coalescing them.

On the other hand, I think that having to put `-web` in our DNS records is a bit of a smell - the workers shouldn't need DNS entries at all, so there shouldn't be any need to disambiguate `blah-web.mesh.govuk-internal.digital` from `blah-worker.mesh.govuk-internal.digital`.

My suggestion is that we merge this for now, but later on we should consider dividing up `modules/app` into `modules/app-web` and `modules/app-worker` so that it's possible to create workers without creating a bunch of appmesh / cloudmap config which is only necessary for the web instances.

```
diff --git a/test/e2e_test.go b/test/e2e_test.go
index dd6212f..fdcdfc4 100644

-	"math/rand"

+	"k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/util/rand"
 )
 
 func TestE2E_Aws(t *testing.T) {
@@ -38,7 +38,7 @@ func TestE2E_Gcp(t *testing.T) {
 func runTerraformAndVerify(t *testing.T, terraformDir string) {
 	t.Parallel()
 
-	prefix := "qs-test-" + randomLowerString(7)
+	prefix := "qs-test-" + rand.String(7)
 
 	terraformOptions := &terraform.Options{
 		TerraformDir: terraformDir,
@@ -80,14 +80,3 @@ func runTerraformAndVerify(t *testing.T, terraformDir string) {
 		k8s.WaitUntilPodAvailable(t, k8sOptions, rancherPod.Name, 10, 5*time.Second)
 	}
 }
-
-const lowerLetters = "abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz"
-
-func randomLowerString(length int) string {

-	}
-	return string(bytes)
-}

It seems like there's still rather a lot of logic in this Makefile that we'd end up duplicating across all projects... Can we look at doing something like the cloudposse/build-harness, where a minimal Makefile is hosted centrally in tardigrade-ci, and pulled down and "included" by the project Makefile?

See: https://github.com/cloudposse/build-harness/blob/master/templates/Makefile.build-harness

Which then gets pulled in with:

```
-include $(shell curl -sSL -o .build-harness "https://github.com/cloudposse/build-harness/blob/master/templates/Makefile.build-harness"; echo .build-harness)
```
